Title:
The phylogenetic position of poroid Hymenochaetaceae
(Hymenochaetales, Basidiomycota) from Patagonia, Argentina
Abstract:
The endemic poroid Hymenochaetaceae from Patagonia,
Argentina, were revised from a phylogenetic point of view on the basis
of ITS and LSU sequence analyses coupled with morphological data.
Arambarria destruens gen. et sp. nov. is proposed for a taxon fruiting
on fallen or dead, standing Diostea juncea and Lomatia hirsuta, and
previously erroneously recorded as Inocutis jamaicensis; it is
distinguished by annual, effused to effused reflexed basidiomes forming
pilei, a monomitic hyphal system, thick walled, yellowish basidiospores
(brownish chesnut in KOH sol.), lack of a granular core in the context
and of setoid elements. Nothophellinus gen. nov. is proposed to
accommodate Phellinus andinopatagonicus, the main white wood-rotting
polypore of standing Nothofagus pumilio and also an important
wood-decayer of other Nothofagus species from southern Argentina and
Chile; it is morphologically similar to Phellopilus (type species P.
nigrolimitatus), but differs in lacking setae. The new combinations
Pseudoinonotus crustosus and Phellinopsis andina are proposed for
Inonotus crustosus and Phellinus andina, respectively. Phellinus
livescens, a taxon that decays the sapwood of several standing
Nothofagus species comes close to Phellinus uncisetus, a neotropical
species closely associated to Fomitiporia but outside its clade
according to previous analyses which is momentarily retained in
Phellinus s.l. Fomitiporella is the genus proposed for the inclusion of
the agent responsible of a white heart-rot that develops in living
Austrocedrus chilensis.
